awd_titl_txt: PFI:BIC - Development, Deployment and Evaluation of an Intelligent Service System for Personalized Early Literacy Learning Using Mobile Devices
awd_abstract_narration:
Early learning is a key time to intervene for subsequent educational and economic achievement. Research shows that reading levels in early primary years can predict high school graduation rates. Effective Pre-K educational intervention programs are recognized as an effective return on investment (ROI) for society via improved employment opportunities, lower incarceration rates, and decreased need for social services. The scalability and ease-of-deployment of smart devices and other digital learning technologies has transformative potential to increase Kindergarten readiness outcomes that is widely accessible and affordable. Especially for children who cannot access quality pre-K education. However, modern digital early educational tools do not possess AI and machine learning algorithms for continuous assessment and modeling of children?s literacy and and oral language skills, nor are they capable of personalization to meet the diverse needs of individual children. The goal of this proposed research is to bridge this gap between the need for personalized interventions for early childhood learning with the ubiquity and affordability of mobile devices. The research team proposes to develop, deploy, and evaluate a system capable of automatic and continuous assessment, personalized content adaptation, and AI-powered educational mentorship to deliver high quality, scalable, and affordable early literacy interventions to young children.


The proposed research will develop a smart system for personalized early learning on mobile devices, by developing three innovative technology components: 1. Embedded student assessment algorithms, that can estimate reading skill from diverse, multimodal data sources including audio, facial expression, and real-time gameplay/usage data. 2. Personalized mentoring algorithms that adapt educational content to individual patterns of behavior of app usage to optimize for individual learning outcomes. 3. Affect-aware content adaptation and personalization algorithms to optimize engagement and learning. These technologies shall be embedded within two novel interactive educational apps. The first is for storytelling and vocabulary development. The second is for reading.  Both use general assessment data, real-time audio, and facial expression recognition to estimate performance and to optimize motivation, engagement, and learning. These technologies will be embedded within industry partner Curious Learning's mobile software platform, which currently delivers early learning software for children to promote early literacy readiness of US kindergarten children. The project will evaluate the ability of these technologies to assess reading skill, foster vocabulary and oral language, and to improve engagement and learning by personalizing the Curious Learning system's educational content to children.

por.por_cntn:
The research objective of this project s to develop an innovative smart system to support young children's early literacy skill development and assessment with a personalized and socially engaging learning companion agent. A social robot serves as a child-friendly learning companion that engages children in a repertoire of educational activities through expressive multi-modal dialog gameplay on a tablet computer and. We developed a suite of interactive learning apps for the tablet to support vocabulary learning and interactive storytelling based on a pedagogically sound curriculum. The tablet also captured general usage data, assessment data, real-time audio data, and affective states via video to support our analysis and evaluation.


Intellectual Merit:

We developed four innovative technology components:

  1. An affect-aware assessment using video-captured expression and audio data to estimate children's word reading skills.

  2. An affect-aware personalization algorithm to adapt the agent's storybook-suggestion and question-asking behavior to enhance children's engagement and learning. The agent learns personalized behavior policies through observing and being rewarded by children's affective engagement, verbal responses to the robot's questions, and vocabulary retention.

  3. An integrated affect-aware personalized learning companion smart system that runs on commercial hardware.

  4. Authoring tools to quickly create interactive stories accompanied by a dialogic agent. 

This work advanced algorithmic and human-computer interaction research to further the development of highly engaging digital learning systems that tightly integrate student affective state understanding with complex models of skill estimation based on human interaction data over time. Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, we could not complete a full randomized controlled trial to evaluate the efficacy of affective personalization. Prior to school closings, we enrolled 217 children from two different at-risk schools, each with four kindergarten classrooms. We captured and analyzed early encounter session logs to assess the success of introducing the social robot smart system into classroom settings. We completed a preliminary analysis of how children's engagement and exploration behavior changed with the learning companion agent. After schools closed, six teachers, and young children's parents, volunteered to host our social robot intervention in their homes. We were able to capture additional interaction data from these children. Our school and home data analysis revealed a broad spectrum of children's exploration patterns using the smart system intervention. We modeled these data to generate a larger dataset to run and evaluate our personalization algorithms. We demonstrated the algorithm's ability to personalize a policy to children with different learning exploration strategies. For instance, for children who use the system repetitively, the personalized policy can nudge them to explore the interactive storybooks more broadly by asking more diverse questions and suggesting a wider variety of books to try. 


Another goal for this work was to generate new human factors knowledge and insights for integrating expressive, affect-aware learning companion smart systems in school and home settings. We co-designed introductory materials and best-practices guidelines with teachers and parents to introduce personalized learning companion technologies into school and home settings. As part of this, we held a series of planning meetings with teachers to design the learning companion intervention to support their existing curriculum. We found this was key to lowering the barrier to adopting new technologies in the classroom. We also introduced and demonstrated the learning companion system to parents at the beginning of the school year to be transparent about the study goals and the types of data the system collected. Not all children were consented to participate in the study, but it was important to not exclude any children from receiving potential benefits from our learning companion system. We carefully designed the log-in system with a teacher interface so that all children could use the system, and only data from consented children were collected. We also held hands-on Robots and AI workshops during classroom time on how AI agents can sense the world and what makes them artificially intelligent. We concluded with a live tutorial on how to interact with the learning companion agent and use the system. 

 

Broader Impacts:

Early learning is a key bottleneck for subsequent educational and economic achievement. The COVID-19 pandemic has significantly reduced classroom time for young children resulting in lost learning opportunities. The potential of providing young children with additional practice and learning opportunities that are scalable, affordable, and supplement what teachers provide is of tremendous value. This opportunity motivates a transformative technology solution capable of automatic and continuous assessment, personalized content selection, dialogic reading behavior and is highly engaging for young children to support long-term usage. The innovative technology developed in this grant has made concrete advancements in this regard. Further, the algorithms and software operate on commercially available social robot and tablet technologies, poised for translational impact.
